title-group.article-title: Density Visualization and Mode Hunting Using Trees

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2002 American Statistical Association, Institute of Mathematical Statistics, and Interface Foundation of North America

abstract.p: Mode hunting, a task related to cluster analysis and density estimation, is carried out in a variety of fields. The objective is to find (distinct) regions of the feature space that have relatively high density. Although existing algorithms for clustering and density estimation can be applied to this problem, they have difficulties dealing with datasets that have large numbers of observations and/or variables. This article presents and discusses a mode-hunting algorithm, based on recursively partitioning the feature space, that is particularly applicable to such data. The algorithm is fast, but avoids many of the pitfalls of other fast methods (e.g., single link clustering). The results from the analysis are amenable to visualization as a binary tree, thus allowing us to gain further insights about the data. We apply the method to a number of simulated and real datasets.
